author: LittleNewton
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I am writing a small dynamic DNS plugins for windows. Now I need to get the ip address of a specific NIC. So I decided to use the pwsh command like:

```powershell
(Get-NetIPAddress -AddressFamily IPv6 -InterfaceAlias 'vEthernet (Ethernet_UCAS)' -PrefixOrigin RouterAdvertisement -SuffixOrigin Link).IPAddress
```

to do it.

But after run this command in a python's subprocess, I got the output like the following.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17793356/138982892-373cce86-f700-4a5f-a7fa-d3fb59d23cd8.png)

It looks like the pwsh.exe has runned with PSReadLine powershell module. But I don't need this.

**Is there any possible way to run pwsh.exe with no module imported?**

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
The output indicates that the user's profile is being executed.  To prevent that, when you invoke PowerShell from Python use the `-NoProfile` parameter.  Also use `-NonInteractive` to prevent PSReadLine from loading e.g.:
```
pwsh.exe -nologo -noprofile -noninteractive -executionPolicy bypass -command "& { ... }"
```

title: How to run pwsh.exe without any Modules.
